description: A broad genre of popular music that originated as 'rock and roll' in the United States in the late 1940s and early 1950s, and developed into a range of different styles in the 1960s and later. It is typically centered around the electric guitar, usually as part of a rock group with a singer, bass guitar, and drums.

subgenres.name: Classic Rock
subgenres.description: A radio format which developed from the album-oriented rock (AOR) format in the early 1980s. It includes rock music from the mid-1960s to the late 1980s.

subgenres.name: Punk Rock
subgenres.description: A rock music genre that emerged in the mid-1970s. Rooted in 1960s garage rock, punk bands rejected the perceived excesses of mainstream 1970s rock. It is characterized by fast, hard-edged music, with short songs, stripped-down instrumentation, and often political, anti-establishment lyrics.

subgenres.name: Heavy Metal
subgenres.description: A genre characterized by loud distorted guitars, emphatic rhythms, dense bass-and-drum sound, and vigorous vocals. Metal subgenres are numerous and diverse.

subgenres.name: Alternative Rock
subgenres.description: Emerged from the independent music underground of the 1980s and became widely popular in the 1990s. It is defined by its rejection of mainstream rock conventions.

subgenres.name: Indie Rock
subgenres.description: Rock music produced independently of major record labels. The term is often used to describe a certain musical aesthetic of sensitive, lo-fi, and often melodic rock music.
